About This Game

HOW FAR WILL YOU GO TO SAVE YOUR ONLY DAUGHTER'S LIFE?

Is there a limit?

Help Owen Wright rescue his daughter from the clutches of the Lonely Hearts Killer, the mysterious figure who kidnaps and murders people who have suffered a love gone wrong.

Unravel the intrigue and put a stop to the whirlwind of crime that has paralyzed this late 19th century British city.

The killer must be stopped so justice can be done!

Features:

  • Discover the clues!
  • Amazing Hidden Object game-play, tricky puzzles and mini-games.
  • Explore a 19th century English city, amazing Victorian homes and meet an intriguing cast of characters!
  • Stop a demented mind and end the killing spree!
  • Save Olivia before it's too late!

The Collector's Edition includes;

  • A bonus chapter with a surprising plot
  • An integrated strategy guide
  • Downloadable soundtrack, concept art and wallpapers
  • An interview with the developers
READ MORE

System Requirements

    Minimum:
    • OS: Windows® XP, Windows Vista®, Windows® 7, Windows® 8
    • Processor: 800 MHz processor or faster
    • Memory: 256 MB RAM
    • Graphics: DirectX® 9.0 compatible or higher video card with 128MB of Video RAM
    • Hard Drive: 400 MB available space
    • Sound Card: DirectX® compatible sound card

8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful
Aargh
434 products in account
133 reviews
Not Recommended
5.6 hrs on record
Posted: June 20
I'm getting tired of this crap. How am I supposed to enjoy the story if the gameplay doesn't make any sense. Everything is just so random... I mean, there is a secret compartment in someone's house containing a puzzle piece that fits in a puzzle in MY house and when I open it I'll find a door handle or something, because that was worth hiding, right? Why the hell is a cuckoo from my grandfather clock hidden on the police station?
You're supposed to be an investigator but everything is so devoid of logic that there is no "investigating" at all, you're just running around collecting random stuff (mostly keys, handles and puzzle pieces). Also because everything is scattered without any logic you either have to write down the location of every puzzle or you have to rely on the hint system constantly.
The thing is I KNOW that it's possible to make a game in this genre that makes at least some sense, you just have to put some effort in it.

The graphics and animations are fine, but the story is really stupid and the characters are either annoying or boring. There is a cutscene where some character starts to explain, well, everything and it takes like 10 minutes... it's so boring that even the main hero falls asleep!

MiMi
2,051 products in account
38 reviews
Not Recommended
4.7 hrs on record
Posted: August 23
Rather short (4 hours) and... Deadly. It lacks everything. HOGs are rarely logical but this one wins the absurdity trophy: the story is totaly silly, clues are hidden in everybody's homes and the characters rarely make any sens and constantly act stupid. The graphics are very dark and dull; and when they're not dark they lack contrast. So it's hard to distinguish anything and it makes everything ugly. It also makes the HOG scenes a torture. The general darkness do get a bit better in the second half of the game but comes back in the bonus chapter.

The animations are horrible, the characters are stiff as wood logs and glide everywhere.The voice overs are quite good but the story and the characters are so silly and boring that you'll fall asleep; there's far too much dialogue. Yes, I did fell asleep during the ending dialogue that lasts 5 long minutes! The music is re used from the Women's Murder Club games (those are good, get them) and clearly doesn't fit this setting and only enhances the general dullness. The mini-games are fine but easy.

I didn't like it at all, it's boring and dull. There's plenty of better HOGs out there, so I cannot recommend this game, even on sale, and even though it's a good cure for insomnia.
Avoid at all cost.

Usagi
1,208 products in account
49 reviews
Recommended
5.0 hrs on record
Posted: September 22
"Oh boy, I love back tracking!" - Said no one ever.

This game is a bit of an odd ball to me. While I enjoyed it better than the first installment I also can't pin point what exactly I liked about it. It's a classic hidden item game, nothing about it breaks any molds. You play Own who is looking for his kidnapped daughter Olivia. It's fully voiced, beautiful artwork, good mini games and hidden item scenes and the story is decent...so I don't know why I feel meh about it.

The story is what I'll touch on first. I liked it, I liked the mystery element and the hunt for a killer. What I didn't like was waiting until the very end to know who did it. There were no clues or build up to the identity, the cops didn't figure out jack and I wasn't given enough info to try to figure it out on my own. Instead, the whole game is spent wandering about and doing puzzles oddly placed in people's homes while Owen shouts and acts melodramatic.

This isn't a huge issue but it really annoyed me, however, the general story itself was alright so I continued playing until the story played out. The mini games and hidden item scenes offered nice challenges and I was able to skip any that I wasn't in the mood to play since there are no achievments attatched to this title to worry about. Game play was fine, except for the map. The map doesn't do much, you can't even use it to move around quicker. Instead be ready to back track a lot constantly.

The game slightly connects to first game, it's set before that one and one of the characters in this game is related to Oscar. Not going to say who, though it seems a bit tacked on as an after thought. You don't need to play one to play the other. Story is alright, the gameplay is enjoyable and the artwork is nice on the eyes. While night a favorite hidden item game of mine, I do recommend giving it a shot.

baddog993
632 products in account
139 reviews
Recommended
3.9 hrs on record
Posted: June 15
I played the first game of this series. Dorian Grey and it was a solid game. This one even looks better. The resolution is better as it now fills most of my screen. The older game I had to play with black bars all around the screen. The hint system has now been improved and tells you where to go instead of having to look at the guide.

The game looks great and the voices are very well done. A very good game so far.

The same group also made a game called Nearwood its another HOG game. I very much liked that game as well. Out of all of those games I enjoyed this one the most. The graphics and story are just a lot more involved and in depth. I really enjoyed listening to the developers explain some of the story lines in the game. Also the puzzles for the most part were a lot better done in this game then the other 2 in the series. If your a fan of HOG then you should love this game. Its spooky and the graphics and sound just pop with flair. A great game.

talgaby
275 products in account
187 reviews
Recommended
4.1 hrs on record
Posted: July 31
Short version: 85%
The Lonely Hearts Murders has one of the best stories in hidden object game history, along with great and many dialogues and a good number of original puzzles. Just don’t expect much logic in level progression, because there is none.

Long version:
The Lonely Hearts Murders is sort of a prequel to Dorian Gray Syndrome, set in London around the turn of the 20th century. It is more of a classic detective story than a psychological thriller. You play as a middle-aged father who, with the help of the police, is trying to save his daughter from the clutches of a serial murderer who “helps” heartbroken young people by killing them.
It isn’t really original, but which murder mystery really is? What is important that excellent actors play well-written characters, and there is more dialogue than in any other hidden object game ever made.

If not for the gameplay, this one could have been a perfect one. But unlike Dorian Gray Syndrome, the progression here isn’t really logical, quite the opposite. Items are always found in the most ridiculous and illogical places, and there are barely enough scenes to really classify it as a hidden object title.
Still… if you want a great story for a casual game, get it. I cannot express in words how much it will be worth it.
